body.p:
Mr. Moses E. Levy (of Florida) intending to
leave here in the morning I steal a few moments from dinner
to address you—as otherwise I should not have time to do so
as I have as yet not had the opportunity of conferring with
my Brother on business matters, to which purpose I must
devote my afternoon & possibly evening also–

We had a tedious time on Friday—only reached Birden
=town at 1 oclock owing to the fog in the Delaware—and
waited there till 3, so as to allow the cars from NYork to
arrive before we should start. In consequence of all which
we only arrived at the wharf at 8 o'clock at night and
after, I may say contending for our baggage, was at last
pursuing my route up our brilliant lively Broadway
Thank God found all well, and somewhat uneasy at the
delay. Your letters to Cousin Isaac I delivered him, and
that for Mr. Hart, handed to his nephew Mr. Davids to convey
to him.

We this day were favored with delightful weather
and altho' not a very full, a very liberal audience to
listen to the Discourse of Dr. Peixotto, at our temporary syna
-gogue, we collected about $270 which really is a most opportune event for our society. Please mention to ma
chere amie Miss R. this fortunate circumstance. to wit the
delivery of the discourse, as I pride myself (perhaps rather

presumptuously) on her sympathy in my behalf-having
been acquainted with the repeated disappointment, I have
(in common with a few others) endured on this account–
Since I am thus fairly embarked on a subject, than which
a more pleasing one could not offer itself, say also that
to the letter and in the very spirit of the commands with
which I was both honored & entrusted by her—have
I fulfilled them. I delivered within a brief hour after
my arrival her large letter to Miss Hortensia[?], and Miss
Pesoa—and I pleased myself doubly last evening in
conveying the small packet intended solely for the use of
Mr. Robert P Noah &c—and in spending a few very agreeable few
hours with the major, his wife & sister. They made many enqui
=ries, to which I responded as well as circumstances enabled
me. Now my dear friend, for the life and soul of me I cannot
separate or detach from my mind the image of her, whom I
so recently left in Philad:–Prepare yourself if you have
courage or patience, sympathy or indulgence, to read the outpour
=ings of a doating passion. Yes if I must allow myself
vanquished, by the blandishments of a cultivated mind, an
amiable disposition, and a model of domestic virtues, for so do
I esteem the idol to which my heart (you may say impiously
or insanely) yeilds its homage & then must you be content to find
my letters filled with such expressions as my feelings dictate.

I had just composed myself yesterday to address those thoughts
which the place and occasion required. I should devote impi
=ous supplication. When the language of the [Hebrew] presented to
my mind the whole detail of Isaacs marriage with Rebekah

Perhaps the name alone first rivetted my attention, be it as it
may. down went my prayer book, and I dont think I ever
perused this interesting narrative with stronger feelings of admiration
at the amiability and benevolence of Rebekah. it is true my ideas
of gallantry could not approve the acquiescence of the servant
suffering her to draw water for the camels and I hope yo[?]
find in our traditions sufficient grounds to prove, that her [?]
nature was not imposed on to that extent. What a [?]
subject for a discourse! Just by way of a bit of peandal[?], small
I ask if one of our southern Belles would do the like for a husband
even were she to know the reward before hand—which the kind Rebe=
kah did not. When you have nought better to write you can touch
on this subject.

When you see Mrs. R Hart, please tell her I delivered her
message to Miss Hendricks. I hope Mr. A has recovered, and that
his family may enjoy better health, and enabled to visit us soon.

Remember me with much esteem to all enquiring friends, and
to those whom I more particularly care for, and admire, you
may strengthen that expression. all which I leave to your judgt..
of me and him or her, as the case may be.

The family desires as usual to be remembered to you and
as ever believe me your friend Theodore.

Forget not, when you write to speak on that subject, the most pleasing, that
my mind can dwell on– and of & one which, every thing will be interesting–
